Also, the newest French dances in use, entryes, genteel and grotesque, chacons, rigodoons, minuets, and other dancing tunes. By Thomas Bray.

notesStmt.note: In the 19 leaves section, verso of leaves are numbered separately; for example, the verso of leaf 1 is numbered 2; however, the recto of leaf 2 is also numbered 2, while the verso of leaf 2 is numbered 3.
Identified as Wing B4291B, reel 2525, of the UMI microfilm set "Early English books 1641-1700".
Cf. Wing B4291B which is dated 1700 and Wing B4291A which has in imprint: for, and sold by, James Young.
Reproduction of original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Dance music -- England -- Early works to 1800.

div.p: Country Dances: BEING A Compo≈øition Entirely NEW; AND The whole Ca≈øt Different from all that have yet been Publi≈øh'd; with Ba≈øs and Treble to each Dance.
ALSO, The Newe≈øt French Dances in u≈øe, Entryes, Genteel and Grote≈øque, Chacons, Rigodoons, Minuets, and other Dancing Tunes.
By Thomas Bray.

LONDON: Printed by William Pear≈øon next Door to the Hare and Feathers in Alders-gate-≈øtreet, for the Author; and Sold by Mr. Playford, at the Temple-Change-Fleet≈øtreet, Mr: Crouch in Princes-≈øtreet near Convent-garden, Mr. Couthbutt in Ru≈ø≈øel-≈øtreet near Convent-garden. And all other Mu≈øick Shops. 1699.

div.head: TO His Highne≈øs the DUKE OF GLOUCESTER.
div.p:
THE un≈øpeakable Honour which your Highne≈øs is plea≈øed to be≈øtow upon this Trifle, is ≈øuch, that a Pen more powerfull than I can pretend to, is not in any mea≈øure able to expre≈øs it; But as your Highne≈øs has been pleas'd to Illu≈øtrate it by your Patronage, I have no rea≈øon to doubt, Sir, Your Pardon for the Authors pre≈øumption, in a≈øpiring to ≈øuch a Heighth, as Dedicating a work ≈øo worthle≈øs in it ≈øelf, that it has nothing but
Your Highne≈ø≈øes E≈øpou≈øal to Recommend it; And as it is Honour'd with ≈øo Glorious, and Youthfull a Champion, to fight its Cau≈øe, I need not di≈øpute, but may with confidence a≈ø≈øure my ≈øelf of its Succe≈øs and reception; For tho' it may want Beauties to In≈øinuate its ≈øelf into the favour of ≈øome, yet the Noblene≈øs of the Patron will a≈ø≈øuredly plead for its Defects, and make it pa≈ø≈øable to all. And ≈øince Your Highne≈øs has been pleas'd to Patronize this, I dare not que≈øtion, but Your Highne≈øs will al≈øo give the unworthy Author the liberty of Sub≈øcribing him≈øelf,

closer.signed: Your Highne≈ø≈øes mo≈øt Dutifully Obedient, and devoted Servant, Tho. Bray.

div.head: A TABLE to Explain the Characters made u≈øe of in this Book.

row.cell: Is when the Men and Women are on their own ≈øides.
Is when the Men are on the Woman's ≈øide, or the Women on the Men's ≈øide.
This for a Strain of the Tune played once over.
This for a Strain twice over.

div.head: To the READER.
div.p: AS the Author has made this Compo≈øition of Dances Entirely New, ≈øo he has endeavour'd to make them as ea≈øie as po≈ø≈øible, to evary ingenious Reader, but if any Gentleman or Lady finds any difficulty in the performance of any of them, he ≈øhall be ready, when ever commanded, to wait upon them with his In≈øtructions.
The Reader is de≈øir'd to Correct one mi≈øtake in the Dance of the Par≈øons Cap, Viz in Page 8. Line the ≈øecond, for [his Wo.] Read [her Man.]

div.head: Round O. Treb.
div.byline: Tune by Mr. J. Lenton, the Dance by Tho. Bray.
div.p: „Äà‚ô´„Äâ Fir≈øt Strain again.

div.head: The Glouce≈øter, a New Country Dance in three Parts.
The Fir≈øt Man begins Improper only in the Fir≈øt Part.
div.p: THe fir≈øt couple turns the ≈øecond couple a whole turn and a quarter, with the right Hands, till they come all on a row cro≈øs the Room; the fir≈øt couple with their Faces down, the ≈øecond couple with theirs up; then all ca≈øt off to the left Hand, the fir≈øt couple till they come below, the ≈øecond couple till they come above; and ≈øo to the end changing with your Woman when you come to the bottom.

div.head: The ≈øecond Part.
div.p: Each Man changing with his own, with the right Hand, 1≈øt. Wo. and 2.d Man turn to the right Hand, and move two or three ≈øteps to the wall, the other cu. following them at the ≈øame time, the 1≈øt. Wo. ca≈øt off, the Man following her till they come below, the 2d. Man ca≈øt up his Wo. following him, till they come into the 1≈øt. cu. place above as at fir≈øt, and ≈øo to the end.

div.head: The third Part.
div.p: Fir≈øt Man put his Wo. from him with both Hands into the 2d. cu. place, 2d. Man pull his Wo. to him with both Hands at the ≈øame time into the 1≈øt. cu. place, then the 2d. Man take Hands with both We. and go quite round to the left Hand, the 1≈øt. Man goes quite round at the ≈øame time, on the out≈øide of them, with his left Hand to them, 1≈øt. cu. ends below, 2d. cu. above, and ≈øo to the end.

div.head: The Duke of Glouce≈øter's March, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe Fir≈øt Man and ≈øecond Woman turn to their right Hand and move to the wall two or three ≈øteps, and clo≈øe their feet; 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man each follow their own Partner at the ≈øame time, and clo≈øe their feet; then 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man turn both to the left Hand round and meet in the middle of the room with their backs to each other, the 1≈øt. Man turns down to the left Hand, and takes his Wo. by both Hands, the 2d. Wo. turns up to the left Hand at the ≈øame time, and takes her Man by both Hands, then the 1≈øt. Man puts his Wo. back, and the 2d. Wo. puts her Man back, 1≈øt. cu. below, 2d. cu. above, then each Man changing with his own .Ã≤Ã≤ The ≈øame thing again :Ã≤Ã≤ Fir≈øt Wo. ca≈øts off to the 2d. Man's place, and 2d. Man ca≈øts up to the 1≈øt. Wo. place, the other cu. following their Partners, at the ≈øame time to each others place, the ≈øame thing back again, only the 1≈øt. Man ca≈øt up into his own place as at fir≈øt, the 2d. Wo. ca≈øting down at the ≈øame time, the other cu. following them to their own places as at fir≈øt .Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. Man and Wo. meet in the middle of the Room, the Man behind the Wo. and clo≈øe their feet, the 2d. cu. do the ≈øame after them, 1≈øt. cu. lead up and ca≈øt off, 2d. cu. lead up at the ≈øame time, and turn ≈øingle from cach other :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: A New Country Dance, call'd St. James's-Hou≈øe.
The fir≈øt Man begins Improper in the fir≈øt Part only,
div.p: THe fir≈øt cu. ≈ølip out from each other, two or three ≈øteps and clo≈øe their feet with their Faces up, the 2d. cu. ≈ølip in at the ≈øame time, and clo≈øe their feet, with their Faces down; then the 1≈øt. cu. in, and the 2d. cu. out as before, 1≈øt. cu. ca≈øt off to the 2d. cu. place, the 2d. cu. leads up the middle at the ≈øame time, and turn ≈øingle from each other. The 1≈øt. Man, and 2d. Man meet betwixt their We. and clo≈øe their feet and clap both their Hands again≈øt each other, then each Man go round the contrary Wo. on the in≈øide to the ≈øame places again. Then the We. do the ≈øame after them, only going round the Men. to the left Hand, as the Men did to the right, and ≈øo to the end, changing places with your Wo. at the bottom. Second pa≈ø≈øage thus,

All four Right and Left three times, each Man begining with his Wo. fir≈øt the ≈øame thing back again, beginning with the left Hand, fir≈øt all four meet in the middle of the Room longways all on a Row, the Men with their right Shoulders to the We. then both Men ca≈øt off to the left Hand quick below the We. with their left ≈øhoulders to each other, then the We. ca≈øt off after them to the right Hand till they come with their right Shoulders to their Men as they were before, then each Man turn his Wo. three quarters round with their right Hand, 1≈øt. cu. lead up and ca≈øt off, 2d. cu. lead up the middle and turn ≈øingle, and ≈øo to the end.

div.head: Lincolns-Inn Garden, A New Country Dance.
Fir≈øt Man begins Improper.
div.p: THe fir≈øt Man put the ≈øecond Wo. from him with both Hands, fir≈øt Wo. pull the 2d. Man to her at the ≈øame time, till they come all on a Row longways, the Men in the middle with their backs to each other, then Men turn both to the right Hand, to each others place as at fir≈øt. We. ca≈øt to the left Hand to their own places as at fir≈øt .Ã≤Ã≤ The ≈øame again, only the We. mu≈øt be with their backs to each other in the middle of the Room, and turn to each others place to the left Hand, Men to the right, to their own places again :Ã≤Ã≤ All lead in and turn ≈øingle, all lead out and turn ≈øingle, fir≈øt cu. lead up the middle and turn ≈øingle, 2d. cu ca≈øt off at the ≈øame time, then all four meet in the middle of the Room longways, Men uppermo≈øt with their faces down, We. with theirs up, and all Foot it .Ã≤Ã≤ Fir≈øt Man ≈ølip out to the left Hand, and in again behind his Wo. ≈øecond Man do the ≈øame to the right Hand, at the ≈øame time, We. the ≈øame after them, fir≈øt Man turn his Wo. a Quarter with both Hands to the left, ≈øecond Man the ≈øame to the right at the ≈øame time; then all lead up, then 1≈øt. cu. lead down the middle, 2d. cu. ca≈øt up :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: The Spring, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe fir≈øt and ≈øecond Man move up two or three ≈øteps, and turn back to the left to their own places again; We. move down at the ≈øame time, and do the ≈øame .Ã≤Ã≤ Each Man changing places with his Wo. with the right Hand, Men with their Faces down, We. with theirs up, then all turn ≈øingle to the left Hand from each other, to each others place; Men being Improper :Ã≤Ã≤ Fir≈øt Man and ≈øecond Wo. goes half round their own Partners on the out≈øide, and turn right Hands round, the fir≈øt Man ends below, the ≈øecond Wo. above .Ã≤Ã≤ The fir≈øt Wo. and ≈øecond Man do the ≈øame after them :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: The Woman's the Man, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. and 2d. Wo. take both hands and ≈ølip to the Wall and foot it twice and clo≈øe their feet, and turn-≈øingle three quarters round, and beckon their Men; then all four meet in the middle of the Room longways, and foot it as before, the We. uppermo≈øt, then We. place their Mens Hands a cro≈øs before them, and pre≈øently afterward make them hold up their Heads, by puting their Hands under their Chins .Ã≤Ã≤ Men ≈øtand ≈øtill while the We. Dance round them, on the right ≈øide of them to their own place again, and foot it twice, and clo≈øe their feet, then take their Men by both Hands, and ≈øett them by their ≈øides, then after ≈øett their own by their ≈øides, then ≈ølip out from each other, the We. to their proper places as at fir≈øt, the Men to theirs and all turn to the right Hand, and foot it as before :Ã≤Ã≤ We. move up two or three ≈øteps, and turn S. to the left Hand, Men move down two or three ≈øteps and do the ≈øame, then We. do the ≈øame thing down the Room and turn to the right Hand, Men move up and do the ≈øame at the ≈øame time, 1≈øt. Wo. and Man meet in the middle of the Room, and turn to the right Hand with their backs to each other, the Womans Face up, the Mans Face down, and foot it as before, then move out to your own places again, and turn to the left Hand, and foot it as before; the 2d. cu. moving in and turning their backs to each other at the ≈øame time as the 1≈øt. cu. moves out and foot it .Ã≤Ã≤ 1≈øt. Man and Wo. meets betwixt the other cu. the 2d. Wo. moving up, and 2d. Man down at the ≈øame time, and all foot it as before, then 1≈øt. cu. cro≈øs over, 2d. cu. meet at the ≈øame time and ≈øtand all four on a Row broadways of the Room, and foot it, all lead up and fall back, 1≈øt. cu. ca≈øt off and cro≈øs over, 2d. cu. lead up and turn S. ‚Ä¢ So to the end.

div.head: Ro≈øamonds Pond, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man take Hands with the 2d. Wo. and left Hands a cro≈øs and turn S. both to the right Hand to their own places again; the 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man go half round, to each others place at the ≈øame time, then the 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man take right hands, and left Hands a cro≈øs, and turn S. to the right Hand to the ≈øame place again, and the 1≈øt. Man and 2. Wo. go half round at the ≈øame time .Ã≤Ã≤ Then the ≈øame thing again till they all come to their proper place as at fir≈øt :Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. change places with both Hands, and turn S. to the right Hand, to each others place, the 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man do the ≈øame after them .Ã≤Ã≤ 1≈øt. Man take his Wo. by both Hands, and put her from him, till they come above, 2d. Man take his Wo. by both Hands at the ≈øame time, and pull her to him till they come below, then the 1≈øt. cu. cro≈øs over and meet below; the 2d. cu. cro≈øs up the middle and meet above :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: The Par≈øon's Cap, a New Country Dance.

head.hi: The fir≈øt part twice, the la≈øt once.

div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man ca≈øt off to the 2d. Womans place, his Wo. following him to the 2d. Mans place; the 2d. Wo. ca≈øt off to the 1≈øt. Mans, place, at the ≈øame time, his Wo. following him half round, then each Man turn his Wo. round with the right Hand .Ã≤Ã≤ The ≈øame thing back again :Ã≤Ã≤ Men and We ‚Ä¢ cro≈øs over with their le≈øt Shoulders to each other, and turn back again to the left Hand, and meet in the middle of the Room, with their right Shoulders to each other, and ≈øtand longways of the Room, then each turn his own a whole turn and a quarter, till they come as at fir≈øt; then 1≈øt. Man, and 2d. Wo. turn to the right Hand and move to the wall and turn half round, 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man follow their Partners, then 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man turn to their left Hands round, and Sett their backs to each other, their Partners following them; the 1≈øt. Man pull his Wo. to him, and put her below; the 2d. Man puts his Wo. from him, and puls her to him above :Ã≤Ã≤ So to the end.

div.head: The Wives Victory, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man take his Wo. by both Hands, and pull her to him, and put her from him in the middle of the Room; the 2d. Man puts his Wo. from him at the ≈øame time, and pulls her to him, till he comes into the middle of the Room, with his right ≈øhoulder to the 1≈øt. Wo. then the 2d. Man and 1≈øt. Wo. change places with the right Hand, the 1≈øt. Wo. turns to her left hand into her Mans place, as at fir≈øt; the 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. go half round at the ≈øame time, to their own Partners place as at fir≈øt .Ã≤Ã≤ The ≈øame again, only the 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. mu≈øt be with their right Shoulders to each other in the middle of the Room, and change places with the right Hand, and both turn to the left Hand to their proper places as at fir≈øt, and the 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man go half round, at the ≈øame time to their places as at fir≈øt :Ã≤Ã≤ Then both the Men change places with their We. with the right Hand, and back again with the left; 1≈øt. Man cro≈øs over with the 2d. Wo. the other cu. do the ≈øame after them .Ã≤Ã≤ All four Hands half round to the left Hand, and all turn S. then all four Hands half round to the left Hand again, and each Man change places with his own :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: Gleamham-Hall, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man and 2d. VVo. go round their own Partners on the out≈øide to each others place, and meet in the middle of the Room, then ca≈øt back again to the left Hand to their own places, as at fir≈øt .Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. VVo. and 2d. Man the ≈øame after them, only they mu≈øt ca≈øt back to their right Hand :Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. cu. cro≈øs over and meet below, the 2. cu. and leads up the middle, the 1≈øt. Man turn to the right Hand above the 2d. VVo. and take her by the right Hand, the 1≈øt. VVo. doing the ≈øame at the ≈øame time, only turning to the left Hand, and take left Hands with the 2d. Man, then all four ≈ølip up the Room two or three ≈øteps and clo≈øe their feet and all turn ≈øingle, quite round, 1≈øt. cu. move out, 2. cu. in, then 1≈øt. cu. in, and 2d. cu. out, 1≈øt. cu. ca≈øt off and cro≈øs over below, 2d. cu. cro≈øs over up the middle at the ≈øame time, and turn S. :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: Braye's Magott, a New Country Dance.
Fir≈øt Strain twice, la≈øt but once.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man goes on the out≈øide of his Wo. till he comes betwixt the 1≈øt. and 2d. Wo. then take his Wo. by the left Hand, the 2d. Wo. by the right and fall back all on a row, and lead in to the middle of the Room, 2d. Man fall back when they fall back, and meet them in the middle of the Room right again≈øt the 1≈øt. Man .Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. Man goeth the Hay with both the We. till he comes to the ≈øame place again beginning on the in≈øide of his own Wo. Fir≈øt the 2d. Man go round the other three at the ≈øame time, to the ≈øame place again with his left Hand to them :Ã≤Ã≤ Then the 2d. Man goes the Hay, beginning with his Wo. fir≈øt, and the 1≈øt. Man goes round with his left Hand to them, as before. This is half the la≈øt Strain. Then the 1≈øt. Man takes his Wo. by both Hands and pulls her to him into the 2d. cu. place, as at fir≈øt, 2d. Man pulls his Wo. to him at the ≈øame time, and puts her into the 1≈øt. cu. place, as at fir≈øt, then each Man turn his Wo. round with both hands. And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: A Conceal'd Health, a New Country Dance.
Fir≈øt Strain twice, la≈øt but once.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. cro≈øs over to each others place, and turn both to the right Hand, and ≈øtand with their Faces out, the other cu. doing the ≈øame after them .Ã≤Ã≤ Then all four go half round to their left Hands, and ≈øtand as at fir≈øt, then Men and We. Right and left twice, each Man beginning with his own Wo. fir≈øt :Ã≤Ã≤ Then all four Hands half round to the left Hand, and each Man change places with his own; the Men being improper, then Men clap their Womens right Hand, and left Hand, and both their Hands again≈øt Wemens, and all turn ≈øingle: This is half the la≈øt Strain. Then each Man turn his Wo. with the right Hand, three quarters round, and clo≈øe their Feet, ≈øtanding all on a row longways of the Room, with their right Shoulders to each other, the Men being uppermo≈øt, and make a little ≈øtop, and then turn the 1≈øt. cu. down, the 2d. cu. up. And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: Short and ≈øweet, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe Men and We. meet in the middle of the Room, with their right Shoulders to each other, the Men uppermo≈øt and ≈øtand all on a row longways the Room; then all turn to the left Hand, and ≈øtand as at fir≈øt .Ã≤Ã≤ The ≈øame on the other ≈øide, only turn back to the right hand :Ã≤Ã≤ Then 1≈øt. Man change places with his Wo. with his right hand, and lead up and turn S. from each other, then 1≈øt. Man turn the 2d. Wo. with the right hand three quarters round, till he come into the middle of the Room; the 1≈øt. Wo. turns the 2d. Man at the ≈øame time with the left Hand till ≈øhe come into the middle of the Room, the 1≈øt. cu. with their Faces up, the 2d. cu. with theirs down and ≈øtand all on a row cro≈øs the Room .Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. Man go back to back with the 2d. Wo. the other cu. the ≈øame at the ≈øame time, then the 1≈øt. cu. cro≈øs over and meet below, the 2d. cu. meet and lead up the middle and turn S. :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: Bartlett-Hou≈øe, a New Country Dance.
Fir≈øt Man begins Improper.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man ca≈øt off and turn up to the right Hand, to his own place, as at fir≈øt, his Wo. following to the 2d. Wo. place, the 2d. Man ca≈øts up at the ≈øame time, and down again to his own place, as at fir≈øt, his Wo. following at the ≈øame time to the 1≈øt. Wo. place, that is half round; then each Man lead his Wo. to the wall and back again .Ã≤Ã≤ The ≈øame again, only the We. do what the Men did, and the Men do what the We. did :Ã≤Ã≤ Then right Hands, and left Hands twice, each Man beginning with his own Wo. fir≈øt, then foot it twice and clo≈øe your Feet, the 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. ≈øtanding with their left Shoulders to each other longways the Room, the 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man the ≈øame; then each Man go back with the contrary Wo. to the ≈øame place again .Ã≤Ã≤ Then all four ca≈øt off to the right Hand half round, and then right Hands and left three times beginning with the contrary Wo. fir≈øt :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: Granadiers Exerci≈øe, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man and Wo. change places with the right Hand, and lead down betwixt the 2d. cu. and turn from each other, the 2d, cu. at the ≈øame time fall back, and ca≈øt up half way, and meet the 1≈øt. cu. with their Faces to each other all on a row, cro≈øs the Room; then the 1≈øt. Man pulls the 2d. Wo. to him below, the 1≈øt. Wo. pulls the 2d. Man to her above, at the ≈øame time, then all turn S. .Ã≤Ã≤ The ≈øame again, only the 2d. Man begins with the r ‚Ä¢ . Wo. and the 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. fall back and ca≈øt a little up as before, :Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. Man ca≈øt off and go round the 2d. Wo. on the in≈øide, his Wo. following him at the ≈øame time, and go round the 2d. Man on the in≈øide till they meet below the 2d. cu. and then cro≈øs over with each other .Ã≤Ã≤ Then 1≈øt. Man cro≈øs over with the 2d. Wo. 2d. Man with the 1≈øt. Wo. after them; then 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. again, the other cu. the ≈øame :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: Love and a Bottle, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man turn his Wo. with the right Hand half round, and both move to the 2d. Man and take Hands with him, and all three go round to the left Hand, till the 1≈øt. Man comes to his own place as at fir≈øt, 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man to each others places as at fir≈øt, 2d. Wo. ≈øtands ≈øtill all this while .Ã≤Ã≤ The ≈øame again only the We. change places with the right Hand, and go to the 2d. Man and take Hands and go round to the left Hand, each to his own place as at fir≈øt, the 1≈øt. Man ≈øtanding ≈øtill as they go round :Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. Man turn the 2d. Wo. round with the right Hand, and fall back from her, the other cu. turn right Hand round as they fall back, then the 1≈øt. and 2d. Wo. meet, and each Man turn his VVo. round with the left Hand, till they come all to their places as at fir≈øt; Then Men Ki≈øs their VVemens Hands, and there VVe. make a ≈øign of Drinking immediately after, by lifting their left Hands, to their Mouths .Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. Man take his VVo. by the right Hand, and then by the left, and change places with her, the 2. cu. the ≈øame after them, 1≈øt. cu. cro≈øs over and meet below, the 2d. cu. lead up the middle and turn ≈øingle, then Ki≈øs the VVemens Hands as before :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: The Lovers Luck, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man turn his Wo. with his right Hand, and fall betwixt the 2d. cu. with his Face to his Wo. and his Wo. fall from him at the ≈øame time; 1≈øt. Man turn the 2d. Wo. with the left Hand, till he comes into the middle of the Room above, his Wo. turns the 2d. Man at the ≈øame time with the left Hand, till ≈øhe comes into the middle of the Room below, then 1≈øt. Man and 1≈øt. Wo. go round each other to the left Hand, till they come to their places as at fir≈øt, and then ca≈øt off .Ã≤Ã≤ The 2d. cu. do the ≈øame after them :Ã≤Ã≤ Then 1≈øt. cu. lead up, 2d. cu. lead down, and all turn S. then back again and turn S. then each Man turn his Wo. round with the right Hand, .Ã≤Ã≤ 1≈øt. The Wo. ca≈øt off to the right Hand to the 2d. Mans place, the 2d. Man ca≈øt up to the 1≈øt. Womans place at the ≈øame time, the other cu. following their own Partners till they come all on a row, the 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. with their backs to each other, then all four turn to the left Hand, 1≈øt. cu. down, 2d. cu. up, and each Man cro≈øs over with his own :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: The Scotch Mea≈øure a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man and VVo. cro≈øs over, and meet below the 2d. cu. and lead up all on a Row, 1≈øt. Man turn the 2d. VVo. round by the right Hand, his VVo. doing the ≈øame with the 2d. Man, then turn your own with your left Hand into your own places as at fir≈øt .Ã≤Ã≤ The 2d. cu. do the ≈øame only lead down all on a Row as the 1≈øt. cu. lead up :Ã≤Ã≤ All four Hands half round to the left Hand, 1≈øt. Man and 2d. VVo. cro≈øs over with each other; then Hands half round to the left Hand again; 1≈øt. VVo. and 2d. Man cro≈øs over with each other .Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. Man and 2d. VVo. Sett and fall back, then Men and VVe. Sett to each other and fall back, 1≈øt. cu. cro≈øs over up the middle, 2d. cu. ca≈øt off at the ≈øame time, then 1≈øt. cu. ca≈øt off and 2d. cu. cro≈øs over up the middle :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: Cupid's Bridge, a New Country Dance.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man and Wo. meet with their left ≈øhoulder to each other, and turn half round with their right ≈øhoulder to each other; the 2d. cu. doing the ≈øame after them, ≈øtanding all on a row longways the Room; then ≈ølip by each other, the 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. with their backs to each other, till they come to a ≈øquare and all foot it; then all turn to the left hand, the 1≈øt. cu. below, the 2d. above, the Men improper .Ã≤Ã≤ The ≈øame again :Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. cu. cro≈øs over and turn the 2d. cu. with the right hand, and ≈ølip by each other, holding right Hands as they pa≈øs by into a ≈øquare, Men with their Faces up, We. down, Men pa≈øs over before their We. and turn back to the right Hand to the ≈øame place again, coming back behind their we. .Ã≤Ã≤ Then We. the ≈øame thing after them, only turning to the left Hand, and pa≈øs back again behind the Men as before; then each Man turn his Wo. with his right Hand round, and all lead up and turn S. 1≈øt. cu. below, 2d. cu. above :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end.

div.head: A Minuet Country Dance, call'd the la≈øt of Twenty.
div.p: THe 1≈øt. Man and Wo. cro≈øs over with their backs to each other, in three Minuett ≈øteps to each others place, and turn to the left Hand with their Faces in, the 2d. cu. do the ≈øame at the ≈øame time, 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. chang places with the right Hand, and turn to the left in three Minuett ≈øteps, the 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man go half round at the ≈øame time, with their left Hand to the other cu. .Ã≤Ã≤ The ≈øame again, only, the 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man change places with the right Hand, and the other cu. change places as before, :Ã≤Ã≤ The 1≈øt. Man lead his Wo. up one Minuett ≈øtep, and five to the left Hand round, till he comes to the 2d. Womans place as at fir≈øt; 2d. Wo. at the ≈øame time lead her Man one ≈øtep down, and five to the left Hand, to the 1≈øt. Mans place as at fir≈øt; 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. fall back into the middle of the Room with their backs to each other, and ≈øtand all on a row cro≈øs the Room each with his Face to his Partner .Ã≤Ã≤ 1≈øt. Man and 2d. Wo. move three minuett ≈øteps to the left Hand, the Man up, the Wo. down, till they come on the out≈øide, the 1≈øt. Wo. and 2d. Man at the ≈øame time cro≈øs over and fall with their backs to each other as before, then each Man turn his Wo. with the right Hand, the 1≈øt. cu. below, the 2d. cu. above :Ã≤Ã≤ And ≈øo to the end,
